context: Windows 8 introduces significant changes to the operating system's user interface, many of which are aimed at improving its experience on tablet computers and other touchscreen devices. The new user interface is based on <a4_0><b9_0>Microsoft's Metro design language<b9_0/><a4_0/>, and uses a Start screen similar to that of Windows Phone 7 as the primary means of launching applications. The Start screen displays <a0_0><b5_0>a customizable array of tiles linking to various apps and desktop programs<b5_0/><a0_0/>, some of which can <a1_0><b7_0>display constantly updated information<b7_0/> and content<a1_0/> through "live tiles". As a form of multi-tasking, apps can be snapped to the side of a screen. Alongside the traditional Control Panel, a new simplified and touch-optimized settings app known as "PC Settings" is <a2_0><b6_0>used for basic configuration and user settings<b6_0/><a2_0/>. It does not include many of the advanced options still accessible from the normal <a3_0><b8_0>Control Panel<b8_0/><a3_0/>.
